Default group. Keyed to a location but can respond to external stimuli.
Mostly Stationary §
Unlikely to leave the area. Could be a choice or not. If they could become Mobile, they should be an AG. Signal them in the Roster to quickly ignore them, like indenting the entry.
Stationary §
Will never leave the location they are in. Not included in the roster, but in the room key instead.
Advanced Rosters §
Variable Areas §
Some AGs could move between areas instead or remaining in the specific group of rooms.
On the Roster list them.


                   
                  Example 
                  
                
Few examples

Area 21 or Area 40.
Area 21 (1-2), Area 40 (4-6) on 1d6
Area 21 (day), Area 40 (night)


Do not go too granular, details should come from play.
Notes/Footnotes §
Adding notes to the AGs is useful for adding specific details to the AG, have tactical notes, if Mostly Stationary, why? and other things to keep in mind or to speed up generation (Names?)
Multiple Rosters §
Could be useful in case of particular scenarios. Day Roster and Night Roster? Normal status and Alert status?
Only useful if there is a big change for some reason, otherwise having small conditionals in individual AGs is enough.
Split Rosters §
For large dungeons, having multiple Rosters simplifies management. One Roster per level, for a megadungeon for example, or some special role for AGs, like VIPs or active response teams.
Rosters & Random Encounters §
Usually one or the other. Rosters for smaller locations, REs for bigger ones.
Hybrid approach is possible by continue checking for REs while playing.
One example is in a megadungeon, a Roster for each level, but RE checks for eventual denizens of other levels passing through.
Another example is to randomize Patrols and keep the other more passive types as AGs.
Roster Restocking §
Restocking is faster, just create a new one for the disturbed areas. Minimal updates needed to room keys in this case, usually.
Passive Locations §
Rosters are useful for active dungeons. A dusty tomb undisturbed for centuries might not require one, for example.
Dynamic Encounter Design §
With dynamic dungeons, you need a dynamic way to design encounters.
Having encounters be combined is common with Actions Groups moving around, so you want to keep each AG a easy encounter alone, since the difficulty goes up if multiple AGs are encountered together.
Principles of Dynamic Encounter Design §

Avoid single boss encounters, difficult to balance and tactically uninteresting.
Single AG encounters still provide some resource ablation even if easy.
Two or three AGs should be a challenging encounter.
Four or more AGs should still be winnable, but should be very heavy on resources or require clever thinking. (rare occurrence and usually AGs join during battle, not all together)
For narrative systems, these principles are less useful imho.
At world level, you can have a summary of the faction (if present outside the dungeon) using Coterie Faction System.

Dungeon Factions §
If a dungeon is completely controlled by a single faction, it’s a Lair.
Instead, more factions can be competing in the dungeon. They give also opportunities to PCs and to disrupt the current status quo.
During restocking, faction dynamics can be updated to reflect current happenings.
Creating Factions §
You will need:

Faction roster
Faction territory
Faction agenda
Faction reaction

Faction Roster §
It’s the Adversary Roster of the area controlled by this faction, with notes about alliances etc.
Faction Territory §
The area controlled. Can be useful to color code rooms belonging to the same faction to better visualize.
There can also be unclaimed areas as well, actually it’s logic between factions.
Faction Agenda §
What do they want to achieve?
Faction Reaction §
Can be the default Reaction table or personalized, based on previous encounters with PCs or simple predisposition.
Random Faction Conflict §
What are the relations between factions? If uninspired, roll them.
Make a Random Faction Table, listing the factions and assign a die.
Add three entries:

Wandering Adventurers: represents other competing groups.
Outsiders: it’s a prompt for factions outside of the dungeon, like another nearby location.
Roll Again Twice: for multi-faction conflicts.

Now follow this procedure:

Faction Conflict Check: roll 1d6. 1 = conflict has broken out.
Roll twice on the faction table. If same faction, could it be internal conflict?
Roll on Faction Conflict Table to determine outcome


[!Faction Conflict Table]










































1d8Outcome1Stalemate Skirmish21 Faction Damaged31 Faction Crippled41 Faction Destroyed5Both Factions Damaged6Both Factions Crippled7Both Factions Destroyed8Factions Unite

Stalemate Skirmish: Largerly unaffectd, maybe minor losses or reinforced defenses.
Damaged: Losses of around 25%. Remove from encounters or AGs.
Crippled: Around 50% lost. Remove entire AGs, modify territory.
Destroyed: Eliminated, territory is empty or occupied by other faction or restocked randomly. Remaining population killed, driven off or enslaved.
Unite: They ally somehow. What happened to leaders?

Workflow-&-Inspiration/Alexandrian/Node-.title: Node-based Design & Mysteries
Workflow-&-Inspiration/Alexandrian/Node-.content:
Three Clue Rule §


                   
                  The Three Clue Rule 
                  
                
For any conclusion you want the PCs to make, include at least three clues.



                   
                  The Inverse of the Three Clue Rule 
                  
                
If the PCs have access to ANY three clues, they will reach at least ONE conclusion.

Basic 5 Node Mystery §
It’s the simplest possible, a single Conclusions structure with 3 nodes.
Step 1: Scenario Concept §
What is the general pitch of the mystery?
Who did it? Why?
Someone murdered? Something stolen or destroyed?


                   
                  From Unchained Mysteries 
                  
                
This is the Step 1 The Spark

Step 2: The Hook §
How are the PCs involved?
Witnesses? Formally invited?
Stumble upon a crime scene?
Someone involves them?


                   
                  From Unchained Mysteries 
                  
                
This is the Beginning

Step 3: The Ending §
What’s the conclusion?
Where do they learn the final answer and/or the final big fight with the BBEG?
This is the last scene of the scenario/adventure.


                   
                  From Unchained Mysteries 
                  
                
This is the Ending

Step 4: Nodes §

Brainstorm cool locations and people related to the mystery.
Aim for 3 Investigation scenes + Hook scene + Ending scene to have a 5 Node Mystery. Usually good for a single session of play.
Brainstorm more than 3 Investigation scenes, then pick the best 3. Can the leftover be merged into the best 3 to make them better?
If you plan on having social only scenes (talking with a single NPCs only), count them as half scene for the 5 scene quota. They are usually shorter.



                   
                  From Unchained Mysteries 
                  
                
This is the Middle

Step 5: Proactive Element §
It’s a bonus scene that can be triggered at any time and reaches the PCs proactively.

Useful to bring the investigation back on track
Or, add more content if PCs are going too fast

Two main options:

The bad guy discovers being investigated by PCs and tries to block/kill them
The next step of the bad guy plan happens (and PCs learn of it)

These proactive scenes should have multiple leads and clues inside, so they can be useful regardless of the point where the PCs are in the mystery graph.


                   
                  From Unchained Mysteries 
                  
                
This is SIMILAR to the Tripwires



                   
                  Adding Dungeons, Heists or Raids 
                  
                
A location of the mystery might be a Micro-dungeon. Multiple scenes happen there, with the three clues for 1 or more conclusions found in different rooms.
Same can be done with Raids or Heists

Step 6: Connect them with clues §
We need to connect the 5 scenes together like in a Conclusion type structure.
In each scene, add 3 clues pointing to the other.
A Revelation List is useful to get started. Use Making Clues for inspiration.

List each investigation scene
For each scene, list the 3+ clues that are needed to reach the same conclusions.

My experience §
After trying building one mystery, I think starting with a list of revelations/conclusions (not a Revelation List) that compose the mystery and the Spark Event (Unchained Mysteries vocabulary), make a Clue List, listing all scenes and sprinkling clues for each revelation there.
This also negates the need for a Revelation List, but maybe it can be useful to build one to check while running.
Step 7: Ancillary Revelations §
There are some conclusions that are not strictly needed for the investigations and will not lead to new scenes. They can still give an advantage to PCs, like preparing themselves better to a future situation.
These are also smaller, side enigmas that give more flesh to the world.
Step 8: Flesh out your Scenes §
Look at the defined scenes and add detail.
If the scene is a location, not different from a dungeon key description.
They don’t need to be single locations. Might be a group of locations together (example: a bar with the manager’s office on the back) or an entire dungeon.

Descriptions of the location or the NPC
Important elements (clues)



                   
                  Prepping Scenes vs Running Scenes 
                  
                
Keep elements of the scene you prep as a toybox of tools you need for that scene, but do not script how they are used. PCs can approach a scene in many different ways, so keep it loose, a bit like LazyDM.



                   
                  Like in Lazy DM 
                  
                
Some parallels with Lazy DM. You would prep for each scene a series of clues (Secrets and Clues step of Lazy DM) and a list of potential scene (Potential Scenes and/or Define Monsters steps of Lazy DM)

Step 9: Running the Mystery §
You can use the Revelation List as a checklist, to be crossed out when the PCs reach a conclusion and tracking all found clues.
If a conclusion is at risk because the PCs haven’t found most of the clues, you will see it immediately and keep an eye on the last clue. (my addition: just remove any DC or barrier to finding it, so it’s guaranteed that the last one is found. Changing a bit the clue to fix it, like OSR does to skip checks if PCs think abut doing the right investigation approach but are unlucky.)
5 x 5 Campaign §
To have different scenarios
Step 1: Design five 5 Node Mysteries §
Create them independently, ideas will come naturally on how to connect them.
Step 2: Connect each Scenario as a Node §
Arrange the five Basic 5 Node Mysteries into a Conclusions pattern.
The clues to other Mysteries should be scattered throughout the whole Mystery currently played. Can be a reward to finish it, can be during investigation, can be in the hook.
PCs might not finish a mystery while starting another, it’s fine. They will get back to it.
For a D&D campaign, a 5x5 Campaign should be ideal for a whole Tier of play.
It would technically be a Funnels with 4 Conclusions inside.
Expanding it §
Instead of using Conclusions patterns, you can insert other things or go with a Node Cloud without a clear structure.
Also different types of scenarios can work as well.
Node types §


                   
                  Node definition 
                  
                
Something from which a clue can be gathered.

These are Conclusions that PCs need to reach. Either as Leads to a location or as a clue to a different type.
Each Node/scenario can be:

Locations

Gives clues by being explored.


Person

Gives clues by observing them or questioning them.


Organizations (also People + Locations)

Gives clues about other nodes usually, similar to People, but in more indirect ways. Can be official or unofficial.


Events

Something that happens at a specific time and usually a specific place. Can be something to prevent happening or something to attend.


Activities

Something the PCs are supposed to do in order to gain 1+ clues.


Thing (my addition)

Something useful or needed. Usually included in Activities, Events or Dungeon/Heist/Raids nodes.


Any of Dungeon/Heist/Raid scenarios (Fractal nodes)
Proactive

They come to the PCs.
Useful as backup to give more clues
Reactions to PCs actions, from People or Organizations.
They can be Events if they are aimed at the PCs specifically.



Non-linear node structures §
Conclusions §

1 Hook scene + 3 (or more) Investigation scene + 1 Conclusion scene. Ideal for 5 Scene Mysteries while keeping them flexible. You can have more than 3 Investigation scenes!
Funnels §

A series of Conclusions with chokepoints to control the flow (and guaranteeing that some conclusions are reached).
Each layer is a free-form investigation sandbox that leads forward gently.
Ideal for classic D&D campaigns, where each layer is for a Tier of play, avoiding PCs skipping to too-high CR enemies.
PCs will unlikely go back to before the
Layer Cakes §

Similar to Funnels, but more gentle in driving forward the story.
Each node in Layer X has a clue to other nodes on Layer X and ONE clue to Layer X+1.
Exploring completely Layer X will give 1 clue for each node in Layer X+1, satisfying the Inverted Three Clue Rule.
PCs will probably go back and forth the layers.
Loops §

All nodes have clues pointing to each other.
Ideal to have multiple entrances (i.e. Hooks). Maybe scattered around different places in a hexcrawl?
Dead Ends §

E here is a dead end. Has no clues inside of him, but can be useful as optional, bonus content that can give an edge later on. Extra treasure? Tactical info?
The leads pointing to E are bonus clues and don’t count for the 3 clues quota.
E doesn’t need to have clues, but it might. They still remain extra though.
Node Cloud §
With time, instead of structuring things like before, you will end up with nodes without a structure, but following both rules. This is fine, leaving the PCs with a sandbox to navigate.
Like a region with different ruins to explore, each has clues pointing to the others, but no order is enforced for each of them.
How to organize nodes for play §
No need to draw nodes and connections. Use the following:
Clue List §
A Clue List is a list of all the clues inside a node.
Useful while prepping the scenario.
Example for a Werewolf killer scenario Clue List: §


                   
                  Note 
                  
                
From https://thealexandrian.net/wordpress/1118/roleplaying-games/three-clue-rule.
Clue list generated by me based on random scenes.


Scene 1: Crime Scene

Over-sized claw marks on the victims (He’s a Werewolf)
Pictures of the same guy on a victim (He’s a former lover)
A broken crate reading DANNER’S MEATS at one of the crime scenes (Check out the Butcher Shop)


Scene 2: Home of Victim 1

Tracks that turn from wolf paw prints to human footprints (He’s a Werewolf)
Love letters written by the same guy (He’s a former lover)
Pictures of the same guy kept in their houses somewhere (He’s a former lover)
A note saying “meet me at the butcher shop” crumpled up and thrown in a wastepaper basket (Check out the Butcher Shop)


Scene 3: Home of Victim 2

One of the victims owned a handgun loaded with silver bullets (He’s a Werewolf)
Pictures of the same guy kept in their houses somewhere (He’s a former lover)
A jotted entry saying “meet P at butcher shop” in the day planner of one of the victims (Check out the Butcher Shop)



Revelation List §
A Revelation List is a list of clues that point to the node. Inverse of a Clue list.
Useful while running the scenario.
To make one:

List each node
For each node, list the 3+ clues that are needed to reach the same conclusions.

Example for a Werewolf killer scenario Revelation List: §


                   
                  Note 
                  
                
From https://thealexandrian.net/wordpress/1118/roleplaying-games/three-clue-rule.
Scene linking done by me with random Scenes names.

For each of these conclusions (he’s a werewolf; he’s a former lover; we should check out the butcher shop) we’ll need three clues.

HE’S A WEREWOLF:

Tracks that turn from wolf paw prints to human footprints. (Scene 2: Home of victim 1)
Over-sized claw marks on the victims. (Scene 1: Crime Scene)
One of the victims owned a handgun loaded with silver bullets. (Scene 2: Home of victim 1)


HE’S A FORMER LOVER:

Love letters written by the same guy. (Scene 2: Home of victim 1)
A diary written by one victim describing how he cheated on her with another victim. (Scene 3: Home of victim 2)
Pictures of the same guy either on the victims or kept in their houses somewhere. (Scene 3: Home of victim 2) AND (Scene 2: Home of victim 1) AND (Scene 1: Crime Scene) (This counts as 3 clues)


CHECK OUT THE BUTCHER SHOP:

A broken crate reading DANNER’S MEATS at one of the crime scenes. (Scene 1: Crime Scene)
A note saying “meet me at the butcher shop” crumpled up and thrown in a wastepaper basket. (Scene 2: Home of victim 1)
A jotted entry saying “meet P at butcher shop” in the day planner of one of the victims. (Scene 3: Home of victim 2)



Making Clues §
Some broad categories for clues, for inspiration: §

Physical Artefacts
Glyphs/Data
Biosignature
Interrogation
Surveillance

Some examples from these:

Correspondence (letters, emails, etc.)
Diaries
Ephemera from a location (matchbook, theatrical posters, tickets)
Official reports
Tracks (to be followed)
Trailing someone
Businness cards
Fingerprints
DNA
Blood type (and fantastical ones)
Graffiti
Financial records
Tattoos
Canvassing (going door to door to start interactions)
Video/Audio recording
Mystic visions/dreams
Shipping info
Books & bookmarks
Background checks/ Bureaucratic records

Clues to the same conclusion should be of different type, to avoid repetition.
Another way to keep them varied, is to look at the skill list of the PCs and choose different ones needed for each clue §
Third way, work from the conclusion of the Revelation List and generate clues based on what you need to include inside. §
Like, I need a clue that points to X, Y and Z. You make 1 clue for each in this scene. You also make sure that all clues are actually present.

Workflow-&-Inspiration/Alexandrian/Runni.title: Running a Dungeon
Workflow-&-Inspiration/Alexandrian/Runni.content:
The Dungeon Turn §

Mark ticks (to track resources, time, etc…)
Make an Encounter Check
Declare actions
Make Perception-type checks as necessary
Resolve Actions, including tracking movement on the map.

Usually a turn lasts around 10 minutes of in game time, but needs to be taken not too precisely, same with distances.
This procedure works best if kept hidden to players, since it leads to more fluid play.
Use this Dungeon Running Sheet to keep track of everything (make a copy) Dungeon Running Sheet.pdf
Ticks §
Use the tracker to tick each turn. If a spell lasts 1 hour, it’s 6 ticks, for example.
Same for torches and other items.
Encounter Check §

Make an encounter check like indicated above.
If an encounter is present, roll on the random encounter table that you are using.

Rolling on activity to determine what the creature(s) are doing is useful.


Determine encounter distance (2d6 x 10 ft)
Make a reaction check (table above or anything similar)

Check 2D Reaction Table.png


Determine surprise, if any (Perception passives or opposing checks for the RPG system in use)

The encounter should appear during the current turn, not obliged to make them at start or end, be flexible.
Dungeon Actions §
Short actions (small movement, quick item interaction, talking) should not be counted.
During the Dungeon Action Declaration step, translate what the players say to the discrete action list.
Movement Action §

Party pace is the speed of the slowest PC.
Dungeon Pace is the movement during exploration of the dungeon, doing it carefully.

Normal Perception checks.


Fast Pace is moving through a space quickly, without checking.

Gives Disadvantage to Perception and Stealth checks (or similar).
No mapping the environment or taking notes.



Combat Action §
After a combat has finished, start a new Dungeon Turn.
If the combat was noisy, make an additional encounter check or have it at 1-2 instead of only 1 result.
Conversation Action §
Considered such if a lengthy debate starts, like if around 10 minutes of IRL time have passed with the players debating.
Helping Action §
A PC helps another. Sometimes they just do it quicker, sometimes the original action is done with advantage.
Lookout Action §
They are focusing on the surrounding encironment.
Make normal Perception checks. All others have disadvantage if doing non-Movement actions.
Overcome Obstacle Action §
When doing something risky or time consuming blocking the way.
Picking a lock, disabling a trap, pushing heavy objects, repairing an object, etc.
Ritual Casting Action §
Casting a spell as a ritual takes the full dungeon turn.
Search Action §
Searching a typical room or 50 ft of hallway is a dungeon action. Bigger will require multiple actions.
Custom / Other Actions §
If something else and it should take 5-10 minutes normally, it’s a dungeon action.
Running Random Encounters §
When getting a random encounter, you need to contextualize the encounter.
Going from “1d4+1 goblins” to “4 goblin cultists of Orcus with skeleton hands which remain active even after they die” is what is needed, for example.
4 Questions to answer when having an encounter:
What makes these monsters unique? §
Ideas (roll 1d5 or choose):

Appearance (scars, hair style, clothing, size…)
Rank (lieutenant vs minions)
Distinctive Ability (special power, magic item)
Behavior / Personality (unusual vulnerability or hostility)
Visible Treasure (jewelry, coin purse, etc…)

Where are they coming from? §
They could be coming from

Another room (look at dungeon keys where the same type is already added)
Nearby, going by logic
outside the dungeon

What are they doing? §
Roll on some Action Meaning table, Activity table (PUM) or from this list:





























































1d12Result1Guard patrol2Escorting prisoners or valuables3Moving raw goods or supplies4Performing a ritual5Going/returning to/from work6Errand/Message delivery7Going to meet someone8Eating. relaxing, singing9Crafting or mining10Training11Perform an experiment12Building or expanding dungeonThis result tells you Where they are going:

Passing by (near where the PCs are)
Passing through (passing where the PCs are)
Coming to the PCs (current PC room is destination)
Stationary (PCs are moving to this room, not the NPCs)

How do hey react to the PCs? §
Follow the reaction table for ideas.
Running Traps §
Find the trap §
If actively searching, they can find it with a successful check. Investigation or similar.
Successful Perception even if not actively searching should give evidence of the existence of the trap at least.
Trigger the trap §
They should have either a Proximity Trigger or an Action Trigger.

Proximity: If the trigger area is entered (pressure plate, magical detection etc…) roll 1d4 for each PC passing through. On 1, it triggers on that PC. This simulates the uncertainty of stepping exactly on the right spot.
Action: triggers when something is done (On chest opened, on door opened, etc…)

Playing the trap §
If found or not, the trap needs to be played.

Description of the trap should involve the environment, not only mechanical effects. This triggers players to think outside the box and find a way to disable traps without the classic tools.
Give the players a chance to react when triggering it, to add meaningful choices to the trap interaction.
Starting ongoing effects can also be fun (now the room is filled with sleeping gas, how to cross it?)
Combine traps with monsters to create unique situations

Workflow-&-Inspiration/Dungeon-Plots.title: Dungeon Plots
Workflow-&-Inspiration/Dungeon-Plots.content:
Common Dungeon Plots §
Defeat the BBEG
Get the Item
Scavenger Hunt (no need to complete the dungeon, can be a source of loot or they need a list of objects to access the last section)
Prison Break
Escape once inside
Variant: Time limit to exit the dungeon, can start when the BBEG is defeated (using magic to keep the dungeon whole, now he is dead) or since the beginning (dungeon filling up,)
Heist / Rescue
Test the PCs
Shifting Dungeon (change layout at some point, or change theme)
Unsafe Passage through it (Moria style)

Workflow-&-Inspiration/Faction-System/Co.title: Coterie Faction System
Workflow-&-Inspiration/Faction-System/Co.content:
Name, Goal, Ultimate Goal, Weakness, Strength, Assets
Goal: short term goal that is achievable by faction.
Ultimate Goal: Why the faction exist. To remind yourself when using the faction.
Weakness: Easy to exploit but not obvious, if possible. Broad and wide enough the it comes up regularly if the faction is going against its foundations.
Strength: Something the faction can leverage to achieve Goal.
Specialization: (My addition) Physical, Cunning, Social or Wealth. If the action made can benefit from a specialization, the Asset Die is rolled with Advantage. Does not stack with Strength.

Physical can be Might for example. A Mercenary Asset assets would have Physical Specialization.
Cunning can be actions of subterfuge. A Thief asset would have a Cunning Specialization.
Social Assets are specialized in political and social manipulation. A political party or a religious group would have Social Specialization.
Wealth Assets provide access to some form of wealth, either monetary or some other mean. A merchant or labour guild would have Wealth Specialization.

Assets §
Tools available to get things done to other faction of the world (non-faction NPCs and non-relevant organizations to the story, like a government in a local city campaign).
They have Evocative Name and Asset Die.
Asset Die: d4 → d12. Efficacy of asset. Can also be number of people in it, if necessary.
How to use it §
Going against the World §
When doing faction turns:

Choose faction
One asset does an action. Action can be anything, go based on expectations.

Decide reward for completing action (new asset, increase in asset’s die or something else in narrative)

If it’s a long-term action, make a clock and mark success for each success.


Roll Asset Die.

If using Faction Strength, roll with Advantage.
If using Faction Weakness, roll with Disadvantage.


On 5+, action succeeds.
On 4, action fails, no repercussions on Asset.
On 3-, Asset Die steps down 1 size.

If it’s already a d4, roll it. On 3-, Asset is defeated during action somehow.





Going against other factions §
If faction action involves other faction, use these rules.

Defending faction chooses an Asset to stop the attacker.

Both sides roll Asset Dice.

On both successes, higher wins.
On both fail, no progress.




If attacker wins, they complete the action.
If defender wins, attacker is blocked and can do a counter action, if wanted. Reward for completion needs to be chosen.

PCs getting involved §
If PCs support a faction with a mission before faction turn, they give +1 to Asset roll.
If they support during faction turn, +1 to asset roll but face consequences on fail.
NB: A d4 Asset needs to be upgraded by another Asset or supported by PCs to ever succeed.
Possible additional rules §

Scale (so a bunch of little factions can feed off a big one while it deals with other big problems)
Wealth (a way to throttle upgrading of assets)
Asset tags and specialties (so that a mercenaries asset is better at fighting than a merchants asset)
Overextending and Acting Cautiously (so that you can achieve more successes or mitigate failures)
Order of events (smaller dice assets should be more agile and act before bigger assets that take time to position and set up)

Source: https://www.mindstormpress.com/coterie-faction-system
also my changes

Workflow-&-Inspiration/Prep-workflow.title: Prep workflow
Workflow-&-Inspiration/Prep-workflow.content:
Main types §

General workflow
Situations

L.O.G. approach
WWN fractal adventure seeds approach



Other types §

Dungeon Adventures (dungeon crawling)
Non-Dungeon Adventures
Investigation

Technical investigations


NPCs
Factions
Environmental (Traps / Tricks / Perilous Environment…)
Settlements

TODO

 Evaluate and implement Node-based design https://thealexandrian.net/wordpress/7949/roleplaying-games/node-based-scenario-design-part-1-the-plotted-approach

 Could be useful for location situations, mapping clues connections, etc
 Leads to heavier prep, but can be ideal for mysteries


 Social Combat OSR/ICRPG style https://deathtrap-games.blogspot.com/2020/08/osr-social-combat-system.html

 Could be a way to gamify a debate or persuasion


 Better codify Technical investigations

General workflow §
High Level Initial Setup §
Steps:

 Generate a set of locations using Settlements and Dungeon Adventures

 For a standard starting point, spiral-out approach, create a Settlement and a couple of external adventurous locations.


 Based on that, create Factions, in order of increasing detail, for each

 Nations
 Main Regional City
 Town/Fortress
 Village (Community, Production focused) / Trading Posts (Trade and logistics) (Mainly between Villages <→ Towns/City, based on geographical utility)
 Ruins/Dungeon/Dungerous locations


 For each Faction, generate NPCs
 Generate News Feeds Events of Factions to have some recent developments
 Decide how each event impacts the other Factions (and nearby locations)

 Generate Adventure hooks and concepts linked to what is happening



After this, do Prep time each time.
Prep time §

 If some time has passed or you see a lull, generate News Feeds for Factions you are interested in. No need to generate for all of them.

 Use Coterie system to define interactions outcomes


 From previous PC actions, adjust Faction statuses
 Prep next Adventure hooks with locations as needed.

Situations §
Resources §
From https://slyflourish.com/anatomy_of_a_situation_castle_orzelbirg.html?rss=1
and https://slyflourish.com/letting_go_of_defined_encounters.html
For all adventures, SlyFlourish steps can be used, especially steps Locations, Secrets & Clues, possible Scenes.
Also Situations prep Record Sheets can be useful if the given situation is there. New situations sheets can be developed as needed.
When prepping a situation, build the following components:

The location. Where is this situation taking place? Often it’s a big location like a castle, a manor, a bunch of caves, a lair, or a dungeon. We ensure the location has multiple ways in and multiple ways to move throughout it.
The inhabitants. Who resides at the location? These residents might be guards, villagers, cultists, or whoever populates the location. Some denizens might be powerful and hostile. Some locals might just be the serving staff or non-combatant villagers. Some areas of the location might have intelligent and organized creatures while others have nasty monsters or ravenous undead. This presents a good mix of options the characters can choose from when dealing with the inhabitants. Few adventurers try to negotiate with an otyugh.
Behaviors. What are the inhabitants actually doing here? What patterns do they follow? What would they be doing if the characters weren’t here? Knowing what their normal behavior is will help us determine what happens when the characters start doing things.
The goal. Why would the characters come here? What do they want? Are they trying to steal something? Recover something? Save someone? Stop a ritual? Give the characters a reason to come to that location and set measures for success other than killing everything.
Potential complications. What complications might take place? Is someone big and powerful returning soon? Is another group trying to steal the same thing? What might shake things up in the middle? These complications help shift the course of the situation as it plays out in ways no one can predict.

Once we’ve planned this situation, let the characters learn about location and inhabitants, and allow the characters to reinforce their goal. Then, during the session, we let the players choose their characters’ approach and enjoy the outcome.
Personal note §
It can be similar to BitD structure, with scores that happen in a place where a situation is setup. This structure reinforces the “Play to find out” approach.
Great to also organize the locations in different zones, like an Hitman level with different rules.
L.O.G. approach §
From ICRPG.
Can be prepped by themes and rolled on as necessity, like Pirate L.O.G..
WWN fractal adventure seeds approach §
Using the fractal adventure seeds, together with WWN tags (or SWM, CWN), can give you great seeds and situations
Dungeon Adventures §
Mainly follow Tome of Adv Design workflow.
Can also use Alexandrian’s Design a Dungeon in alternative.
Can be useful to use The Adventure Crafter for the initial seed.
Can also use Dungeons & Dilemmas to create a storied dungeon and how it influences nearby spaces.
Fast dungeon creation workflow: §

First Pass:

Decide on high level overview of dungeon. (Dungeon & Dilemmas provides fast tables for this)

Who built it?
Original need fulfilled?
If ruined, cause of ruin?
Who are the current factions inside?
Which interactions with outside? Simply being known still counts.


Make a small list of needed locations and NPCs
Make a quick pointcrawl of various places, no need to think in detail. Use Excalidraw.

You can use Cyclic based design for a quick first draft.




Second Pass:

Identify clusters of nodes. Give a common theme to each. Can be environmental or faction or whatever.
Modify node connections as needed, add a description of what’s in each node.


Third Pass:

Populate each node/room.

Empty rooms can be useful for exposition and clues.


Generate traps if needed (Prepless GM has some useful tables to generate them)

Who placed them?
What are they protecting?
Always foreshadow them.


Place monsters (Consider motivations etc like in Dungeon & Dilemmas)

Generate Component based ones for puzzle-like combats




Fourth Pass:

Consider making a detailed map in Dungeon Draft or 3D Canvas. Maybe only of important rooms.



Additional resources §
All the xWN books by Crawford. Meaning Tables of General Flow
Non-Dungeon Adventures §
The Adventure Crafter for initial seed.
Additional resources §
All the xWN books by Crawford. Meaning Tables of General Flow
Investigation §
The Adventure Crafter for initial seed.
Unchained Mysteries - Investigation & Mystery prep to use Three Clue Rule.
Node-based Design & Mysteries as well from Alexandrian.
Mystery Matrix Flow if a random generation is wanted.
For group play, I can always have a Discovery Check be Yes or Excep Yes to avoid lulls in rhythm.
Making a Timeline of events from Unchained Mysteries as a pre step can help in quickly setting up scenes.
Technical investigations §
https://discord.com/channels/517880617854304256/1153683350956015617
TODO Define better to be system agnostic.

I’ve been playing around with a mod to the DiS system. Complex items have 1-6 condition points. Using my rundown ship as an example, I list a bunch of systems and assign total cond points. But also for a room I go more micro, like an airlock, and assign systems for that with cond too. Anything that you have to interact with to perform a function. So for the airlock I have two doors, activation terminals inside and out of the airlock. The pumps (which I say is outside the space craft). I then make a “reliability” for each cond point (on the fly as needed for a system). Failed cond points are broken and I roll an effect on a random table that gets triggered if you use the system. Its a d66 table where the first roll is the type of system: electrical, mechanical, chemical, software, and void (a DiS thing for sort of weird cosmic horror type things). I call that a “degradation”. So a computer terminal might have 2 cond. And if I use it I might find out one cond is broken and has a degradation. I find out its electrical and it randomly shocks its user if they touch it. I also add random failures on use. Another “reliability check”. On fail, another cond breaks and has a degradation. But also on these failures you roll on a different table of acute failures. So if you activate a manual release in the airlock door you might get a failure, mechanical, something internal snaps and breaks when you try the door. The manual release is no longer an option until the cond point is repaired.





NPCs §
Backstory using The Adventure Crafter.
Appearance, motivations etc from expectations and Meaning Tables of General Flow.
Other tools:

folder 000.Toolbox\NPC Creation & Emulation
SUM

Factions §
Courts from WWN can be a good way to also simulate them.
Use Coterie Faction System.
Use News Feed Place and Character Feeds from MM35, in addition to Coterie Faction System.
Faction Workflow §
Coterie Faction System for general narrative Context and News Feeds
Can use https://icastlight.blogspot.com/2022/01/grendel-mendel-using-punnett-squares.html to design monsters in factions. Good to provide mechanics to a themed faction.
Environmental (Traps / Tricks / Perilous Environment…) §
Traps Generation §

Meaning Tables
000.Toolbox/General prep/Prepless GM, page 83
Tome of Adv Design page 347 to 370
(OSR style) 000.Toolbox/Tricks_Empty_Rooms_and_Basic_Trap_Design page 18 and page 28

Tricks Generation §

Meaning Tables
(OSR style) 000.Toolbox/Tricks_Empty_Rooms_and_Basic_Trap_Design page 13
Tome of Adv Design page 294 to 345

Settlements §
Resources:

Meaning Tables
000.Toolbox/Settlements/Fantasy/Spectacular Settlements
000.Toolbox/Sandbox Generator
Watabou web generator for maps

Prioritize Spectacular Settlements for fantasy generation.
It can be also used for other things, tables seem pretty generic in the end.

Workflow-&-Inspiration/Traps,-Tricks,-Ha.title: Traps, Tricks, Hazards workflow
Workflow-&-Inspiration/Traps,-Tricks,-Ha.content:
Inspiration https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3YZakNJBzmA
Also Tome of Adventure Design and WWN
Consider:

No single solution.

Categories §
Puzzles §
Can be an actual puzzle or some hidden way to reach or do something
- Should be resolvable by multiple solutions
- Simple: Open pit with spike, how to cross?
- Complex: A statue is blocking a passage, too heavy to move quickly. One column nearby can rotate and has slits to place rods inside. The coming corridor has metal and long torches that could be used as rods to lever the rotation. Other possible solutions: PC gets strong and rotates directly, use other way to make a lever, use an applicable spell for it.
- At least one solution should be available nearby and be ready to be given hints in case of PCs stuck
Tricks §
Catch all term from other categories. Possibly a magic/tech device of unknown function, used blindly
- A portal to unknown location?
- Could be harmless and have some quirky temporary or permanent effect.
- Can cause danger if used blindly.
- Examples: God statue that can give good or bad stuff. Need to know the god lore and can be activated blindly. Can give bad stuff if used badly and good stuff if used well.
- To be used sparingly or often but usually harmless/armosphere giver/
Actual Traps §
Placed with Intent, Trigger should be hidden
- Consider adding Disarm mechanism that can be found if it makes sense for original user usability and safety.
- Consider Survival check in 5e or Tracking skills to show signs of past usage (wear signs around moving parts, damage to surfaces from acid fluids etc)
- Consider foreshadowing of traps (previous victims, NPC dying on it)
- Consider showing the trap but not the trigger, to have tension
- Can be Complex with chain mechanisms
- Needs to make sense on the reasoning behind them.
- Old traps could not function correctly (use some luck roll to see if the trap trigger)
- Think of a way for PCs to use the traps against inhabitants
- Use only once each type. No repetition.
Threats §
Immediate dangers that need action to overcome. Trash compactor, rolling boulder, etc
Can be activated by Trap triggers or be natural.
Hazards §
Danger like trap, but natural or lacking original Intent to be a trap. Wear down rope bridge, flooded room with some electricity around there
Rewards §
Ideas:
Ways to baypass future traps/threats.
Gold
Useful Objects for plot
Magical objects

Workflow-&-Inspiration/Unchained-Mysteri.title: Unchained Mysteries - Investigation & Mystery prep
Workflow-&-Inspiration/Unchained-Mysteri.content:
Unchained Mysteries approach §
TLDR:
Basically relies on a web on NPCs with objectives and connections between them.
Also, the kernel of Mysteries is: Someone wants to keep something hidden. The investigators dig to unveil it.
This leads to have a backstory of the NPCs involved, giving a good context for the DM to remain flexible during play and easily prep sessions.
Step 1: The Spark §
First Step, the Spark:

Define a transgression (can be monetary, physical or moral/social). Someone did something that they want to keep secret. Someone else has lost something from this event.

We have our first 2 NPCs and a connection.


From there, expand to other NPCs connected to the first 2 in any way. All are impacted more or less, good or bad. Respond to these questions:

How do they experience this impact?
What do they intend to do about it?


Can be fractal as needed, but having 4-8 NPCs total should describe a dynamic situation.

Final result at this point: A list of NPCs and an ongoing situation.
It’s already playable by the GM.
THIS IS ALREADY ENOUGH FOR SIMPLER ADVENTURES.
Step 2: The Timeline §
Go back or forward in time and define other events that are connected to the spark event.
The Past §
Look at the NPCs, especially the ones closer to the Spark.

What choices did they make?
What events must they have experienced to bring them to this moment?

This can introduce new NPCs and how they are involved.
Don’t go too much behind, otherwise it’s just history.
To have a meaningful event, the effect of this past event must still be felt in the present. For example, someone benefitting from this event, or suffering from it to this day.
The Future §
Similar to Fronts in Dungeon World.
How will the situation evolve without the PCs?
For each NPCs:

What will they do next?

This can generate new NPCs and also new transgressive events, from desperation or retaliation.
Step 3: Key Events §
From this timeline, make a list of the most critical events. Can be dramatic, but also important from a financial or romantic POV.
For each of these events, note down finer details.
Don’t need to be clues, but should be better detailed.

Things the PCs might ask or do

Possible questions to answer:

Where, exactly, did the event take place?
What are the finer details of the significant actions taken during the event?
Who was present? What was their reaction to what transpired?
What did they do immediately afterward?
Did any unexpected things intrude on the proceedings, or did any of the people involved make a mistake or suddenly change course from their original intentions?

Extra §
How to handle supernatural elements? §
Should not be the the mystery’s focus.
A list of possible supernatural elements:

People, based on ancestry, culture (alien, fantasy, whatever). They remain people though, but can have weird implications of social behaviours or how they do things thanks to innate powers or abilities, for example.
Location property. Can be something happening in the scenario, breaking reality somehow and pushing people to act.
As by-product of ordinary people transgression.
As catalyst of people drama, like vampires, warewolves.

How do people in a community react to this sudden stress? That’s the point of the story, not the supernatural.


In general, if resolving the supernatural issue brings back the status quo, you need to add more troubles between NPCs.

NPCs should be akin to DM PCs. What would they do in the given situation?
Tripwires §
Aka, Mythic’s Keyed Events.
If condition verifies, a NPCs changes their behaviour.
Should be used on major NPCs.
Actual Play §
Beginning §
Opening Scenes Tips §

Opening scene should not be about info gathering. 4 cases:

If PCs have a formal or professional reason to investigate (investigators)

Instead on initial location, choose a NPCs and see who might be around following their agenda. Can be ally, with their own agenda on how to do things.

Key thing: NPCs need to be following their plans, which will result in a kind of interference in normal clue gathering.




If PCs don’t have a reason to get the hook:

Put them in the direct path of one of the NPCs following their agenda.

Not as quest giver, but as a dramatic interaction.

Test: Is NPC using the PCs to accomplish something they can’t do themselves? If yes, quest giver, bad. If not, peer interaction, good.






PCs become involved indirectly through the interaction of 2+ NPCs.

The PCs are involved in the consequence of this interaction.


One of PCs backstory issues is the centre of the scene.



Opening  scene ideas:

Some aspect of a NPC’s well-being is suddenly placed in the PCs’ hands.
A NPC takes advantage of a PC personally or professionally, intentionally or opportunistically.
A PC witness a NPC doing something that should not have been observed.
A NPC attempts to harm a PC directly.

Middle §
Mystery stories are character dramas about digging up things other would rather stay buried.
GM needs to play NPC’s desire to keep it buried.
Clues §
Should never just point to another source of info (lead).
Expository Clues §
Reveal facts about past events on the timeline.
Found by looking for them.
Often found my minor NPCs and reported on by social interaction or other report.
Scenes about it should be kept short but truthful to explain the situation.
Dramatic Clues §
Exposes the dramatic stakes of the situation, revealing something emotional or psychological about a NPC OR illuminates a relationship between two NPCs.
How to manage the moment to moment gameplay §
Do a list of Clues, divided in Expository or Dramatic like in LazyDM.
In a separate, new section of the LazyDM steps, for each Key Event, answer the questions in Step 3 Key Events.
Possible structures of Interpersonal Drama §
The focus of any scene should be: How do the characters treat each other?
Aka, focus should be on exposing a Clue, which gives info about 1+ NPCs.
A list of dramatic tensions that often arise between characters in mysteries.
• Tensions between personal responsibility and obligations and the needs of the investigation. (These tensions often arise between close relations).
• Tensions over how the investigation should be focused or proceed, especially over the handling of persons of interest and other sensitive information. (These tensions can often arise between allies).
• Tensions that arise when characters try to take advantage of each other to further a personal agenda. (This, of course, can be any kind of antagonistic encounter but an often overlooked version of this is the trading of leverage in an interrogation).
Also, NPCs should continue to further their own goals, not staying idle waiting for investigators to go away.
Ending §
TODO page 53
The discovery of a solutions opens up the question of what to do about it.
The solution is not only Who, but also How and Why.
Also, do PCs need proof of all of this?
TODO finish

Workflow-&-Inspiration/Wallet-Stations-T.title: Wallet Stations Text
Workflow-&-Inspiration/Wallet-Stations-T.content:
Wallet Stations (Public) §
Create a space station by rolling a handful of six sided dice, then assemble as follows:

End Point: Connects to 1 die
Connector: Connects to 1 or 2 dice
Splitter: Connects to 1, 2, or 3 dice
Crossway: Connects to 1, 2, 3, or 4 dice
Core: Stack all, must connect to 2+ dice
Bay: Merge all, connects to 1 die

For each room, add its value to all connected dice to find its contents. Bays are one room with all dice summed. See back for the Core.

XX
XX
Scanning Array
Capsule Hotel
Hydroponics
Spacer Bar
Med Clinic
Holo VR Room
Bio-Processing
Auto-Diner
Meat Extruder
Research Lab
Neural Uplink
Nano-Forge
Terrarium
Cloning Tanks
Condominiums
18-19. Salvage Shop
20-21. Auto-Factory
22-25. Fuel Refinery
26-30. Repair Dock
31+. Hangar

Place a docking point on an extremity.
Back §
The Core’s size indicates power supply. Sum the value of all connected dice for contents: odd is the first option, even is the second.


Solar Panels


Fission Pile

Artificial Intelligence Core
Hyperspace Beacon



Fusion Reactor

Magnetic Accelerator
Hyperspace Beacon



Hyperspace Tap

Ansible Relay
Hyper-Scanning Array

index.title: Home
index.content:
Hello!
I’m Davide and this my space where I post my solo TTRPGs sessions, in case anyone is curious :)
Assassin’s Creed of Duskvol (ongoing) §
A Blades in the Dark game in the canonical setting of Duskvol, but with a twist: my crew is a group of Assassins from the videogame Assassin’s Creed, trying to eradicate Templar presence in Duskvol.
Using Blades in the Dark and Mythic GME 2e.
Disclaimer: I work on the AC series, but everything here is non-canon and my “fanfiction” only, if there was even a need to specify. It’s not even our own history background afterall…
Sessions §
Session 1
Session 2
Session 3
Session 4
Session 5
Session 6
Session 7
Traveller - Pirates of Drinax (ongoing) §
My try at Mongoose Traveller 2e, playing the Pirates of Drinax sandbox campaign.
Using Mongoose Traveller 2e and Mythic GME 2e.
Sessions §
Session 1
Session 2
Session 3
Fantasy Savage Worlds Megadungeon Delve (coming soon) §
A fantasy dungeon delving using Savage Worlds Adventure Edition, Hexcrawl Generator, Spectacular Settlements.
Fantasy Savage Worlds (stopped) §
A fantasy hexcrawl using Savage Worlds Adventure Edition and a mix of tools. Lots of experimentation :)
Since I was not feeling the start of the story, I rebooted it in Fantasy Savage Worlds Megadungeon (ongoing).
Sessions §
Session 1
Session 2

support/inlineScripts/arrows.sfile.title: arrows.sfile
support/inlineScripts/arrows.sfile.content:
Shortcuts for writing various arrows:

→←↑↓
▶◀▲▼
⇒⇐⇑⇓
↔↕⇔⇕⇄⇅
↗↘↖↙
↪↩↻↺↝↜

__
^(?:arrow right|\-\>)$

__
return "→";
__
→ - → (RIGHT arrow).
- Alternative: arrow right
__
^(?:arrow left|\<\-)$

__
return "←";
__
<- - ← (LEFT arrow).
- Alternative: arrow left
__
^(?:arrow up|\-\^)$

__
return "↑";
__
-^ - ↑ (UP arrow).
- Alternative: arrow up
__
^(?:arrow down|\-v)$

__
return "↓";
__
-v - ↓ (DOWN arrow).
- Alternative: arrow down

__
^(?:tri right|\|\>)$

__
return "▶";
__
|> - ▶ (RIGHT triangle).
- Alternative: tri right
__
^(?:tri left|\<\|)$

__
return "◀";
__
<| - ◀ (LEFT triangle).
- Alternative: tri left
__
^(?:tri up|\|\^)$

__
return "▲";
__
|^ - ▲ (UP triangle).
- Alternative: tri up
__
^(?:tri down|\|v)$

__
return "▼";
__
|v - ▼ (DOWN triangle).
- Alternative: tri down

__
^(?:arrow dbl right|\=\>)$

__
return "⇒";
__
=> - ⇒ (RIGHT double-arrow).
- Alternative: arrow dbl right
__
^(?:arrow dbl left|\<\=)$

__
return "⇐";
__
<= - ⇐ (LEFT double-arrow).
- Alternative: arrow dbl left
__
^(?:arrow dbl up|\=\^)$

__
return "⇑";
__
=^ - ⇑ (UP double-arrow).
- Alternative: arrow dbl up
__
^(?:arrow dbl down|\=v)$

__
return "⇓";
__
=v - ⇓ (DOWN double-arrow).
- Alternative: arrow dbl down

__
^(?:arrow leftright|\<\-\>)$

__
return "↔";
__
<→ - ↔ (LEFT / RIGHT arrow).
- Alternative: arrow leftright
__
^(?:arrow updown|\^\-v)$

__
return "↕";
__
^-v - ↕ (UP / DOWN arrow).
- Alternative: arrow updown
__
^(?:arrow dbl leftright|\<\=\>)$

__
return "⇔";
__
<=> - ⇔ (LEFT / RIGHT double arrow).
- Alternative: arrow dbl leftright
__
^(?:arrow dbl updown|\^\=v)$

__
return "⇕";
__
^=v - ⇕ (UP / DOWN double arrow).
- Alternative: arrow dbtl updown
__
^(?:arrow left right|\<\/\/\>)$

__
return "⇄";
__
<//> - ⇄ (LEFT arrow & RIGHT arrow).
- Alternative: arrow left right
__
^(?:arrow up down|\^\/\/v)$

__
return "⇅";
__
^//v - ⇅ (UP arrow & DOWN arrow).
- Alternative: arrow up down

__
^(?:arrow rightup|\-\^\>)$

__
return "↗";
__
-^> - ↗ (RIGHT / UP arrow).
- Alternative: arrow rightup
__
^(?:arrow rightdown|\-v\>)$

__
return "↘";
__
-v> - ↘ (RIGHT / DOWN arrow).
- Alternative: arrow rightdown
__
^(?:arrow leftup|\<\^\-)$

__
return "↖";
__
<^- - ↖ (LEFT / UP arrow).
- Alternative: arrow leftup
__
^(?:arrow leftdown|\<v\-)$

__
return "↙";
__
<v- - ↙ (LEFT / DOWN arrow).
- Alternative: arrow leftdown

__
^(?:arrow curve right|u\>)$

__
return "↪";
__
u> - ↪ (RIGHT curve arrow).
- Alternative: arrow curve right
__
^(?:arrow curve left|\<u)$

__
return "↩";
__
<u - ↩ (LEFT curve arrow).
- Alternative: arrow curve left
__
^(?:arrow clock|c\>)$

__
return "↻";
__
c> - ↻ (CLOCKWISE arrow).
- Alternative: arrow clock
__
^(?:arrow cclock|\<c)$

__
return "↺";
__
<c - ↺ (COUNTER-CLOCKWISE arrow).
- Alternative: arrow cclock
__
^(?:arrow wavy right|\~\>)$

__
return "↝";
__
~> - ↝ (RIGHT wavy arrow).
- Alternative: arrow wavy right
__
^(?:arrow wavy left|\<\~)$

__
return "↜";
__
<~ - ↜ (LEFT wavy arrow).
- Alternative: arrow wavy left
